OriginalSource.Creator: Terese Winslow
OriginalSource.Comment: Removed label inside clamp (in main image and inset) that has a number 5 on it.

Changed the color of the label “Vein” to black, and unbolded the label “PICC” in the inset; closed the clamp on the tubing in the main figure; made the IV tubing coming out of the bottom of the tube darker in the inset.

Moved the PICC insertion point up so that it is clear that it is above the crease in the arm; moved the veins and the catheter so they don't cross over the armpit up at the shoulder area; added "Superior" to the vena cava label and removed "in the arm" from the Vein label; shortened the catheter at the point where it approaches the heart so it doesn’t look like it is going into the heart; added a clear plastic dressing over the PICC line in the inset; added the label "Intravenous line" pointing to the tubing coming out the bottom of the access part of the catheter in the inset; and removed the extra space in the title after the acronym PICC in parens.

ContentDescriptions.ContentDescription: Peripherally inserted central catheter (PICC); drawing of a PICC line that goes from a vein in the upper right arm to a large vein above the right side of the heart called the superior vena cava. An inset shows a PICC line in the arm with a clear plastic dressing over it. An intravenous line attached to the PICC is also shown.

Captions.MediaCaption: Peripherally inserted central catheter (PICC). A PICC is a thin, flexible tube that is inserted into a vein in the upper arm and guided (threaded) into a large vein above the right side of the heart called the superior vena cava. It is used to give intravenous fluids, blood transfusions, chemotherapy, and other drugs. It is also used for taking blood samples. A PICC line may stay in place for weeks or months and helps avoid the need for repeated needle sticks.
